definition: A little something extra, often given as a bonus or treat.
etymology: From Louisiana French, adapted from Spanish 'la ñapa.'
example: The bakery gave us a lagniappe — a free king cake baby charm.

definition: Local term for the grassy median in the middle of a street, often used for parade watching.
etymology: Named during the early 1800s to mark neutral territory between French and American settlers.
example: We’ll meet on the neutral ground side of St. Charles Avenue.

definition: Traditional shout from parade-goers asking float riders to toss throws.
etymology: Became popular in the early 20th century as bead-throwing traditions grew.
example: Kids line the street yelling ‘Throw me something, mister!’ at the floats.

definition: Phrase locals use to describe the Mardi Gras season.
etymology: Derived from New Orleans rhythm and blues culture.
example: Once Twelfth Night comes, it’s officially Carnival time.

definition: Wooden ladders with seats attached on top, used by families to give children a safe view at parades.
etymology: Local invention for parade safety and visibility.
example: The kids watched the parade from their ladder seats.

definition: Ticketed seating areas along parade routes offering unobstructed views.
etymology: From general use of 'grandstand' for spectator seating.
example: Visitors booked grandstand tickets to watch Endymion.

definition: The parade-viewing side along the grassy median.
example: Locals prefer the neutral ground side for easier access.

definition: Staged scenes performed at krewe balls, often depicting mythological or historical themes.
etymology: From French 'tableau vivant,' meaning living picture.
example: The Krewe of Comus ball opened with elaborate tableaux.

definition: Young women formally introduced to society at Carnival balls.
etymology: French 'débutante,' meaning beginner or first appearance.
example: The Rex Ball presents New Orleans debutantes each year.

definition: Most Carnival balls are private, requiring formal invitations.
example: Securing an invitation to a Mardi Gras ball is a coveted honor.

definition: A masquerade ball where guests wear masks.
example: The Zulu Bal Masqué is a highlight of Carnival season.

definition: The title bestowed on the monarch chosen by the Krewe of Rex each year.
example: The King of Carnival rides at the head of the Rex parade.

definition: The female counterpart to the King, usually a young debutante.
example: The Queen of Carnival is presented at the Rex Ball.

definition: Senior female court member attending to the Carnival Queen.
example: The Maid of Honor assists the Queen at the ball.

definition: Children in costume who attend the King and Queen during parades and balls.
example: Royal pages carry the King’s train during the ball.

definition: Rural Cajun Mardi Gras celebration where participants go house-to-house collecting ingredients for a communal gumbo.
example: The courir de Mardi Gras features costumed riders on horseback.

definition: Famous Cajun Mardi Gras celebration held in Mamou, Louisiana.
etymology: Named for the town of Mamou.
example: Mamou Mardi Gras is known for its lively music and traditions.

definition: Second largest Mardi Gras celebration in Louisiana, after New Orleans.
example: Lafayette hosts parades and concerts throughout Carnival.

definition: Mardi Gras celebration in Mobile, Alabama, considered the oldest in the U.S.
example: Mobile’s Mardi Gras predates New Orleans by decades.

definition: Ticket bundles including seating, food, and drinks for parade viewing.
etymology: Marketing term for parade tourism services.
example: Visitors booked parade packages for Endymion weekend.

definition: Guided tours explaining Mardi Gras history, costumes, and traditions.
example: Mardi Gras tours often include a stop at Mardi Gras World.

definition: Many krewes host their balls in major hotel ballrooms.
example: The Sheraton ballroom hosts several Mardi Gras balls.

definition: Krewe that holds the first official Carnival ball of the season on January 6.
example: The Twelfth Night Revelers open Carnival season.

definition: The Monday before Mardi Gras, featuring riverfront festivities.
example: The King of Rex arrives on a boat at Lundi Gras.

definition: January 6th, religious feast day that begins Carnival season.
example: Epiphany marks the first king cakes of the season.

definition: The full period from Epiphany to Mardi Gras Day.
example: Carnival season lasts up to two months.

definition: Torchbearer tradition dating to the 19th century to light night parades.
example: The flambeaux tradition was once the only light source for parades.

definition: Year the Krewe of Comus was founded, establishing modern Carnival traditions.
example: Comus 1857 introduced themed floats.

definition: Began in the early 1900s as a signature throw from Zulu.
example: Zulu coconuts became prized historical throws.

definition: Purple, gold, and green colors established by Rex in 1872.
etymology: Selected to represent justice, power, and faith.
example: Rex’s choice of colors set Mardi Gras tradition.
